Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Stochastic Processes in High Dimensions: from Asymptotic Analysis to Algorithms

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award is to devise and study algorithms for large-scale random systems where direct computation is infeasible despite today's ever-increasing availability and affordability of computing resources. This project focuses on three stylized settings: (1) The project aims to introduce new Monte Carlo algorithms for rare event simulation and to show how these are widely applicable, including in cases where no efficient algorithms have currently been found. (2) The project aims to devise and assess the performance of resource allocation algorithms in large-scale stochastic networks such as computer clouds, specifically to increase the understanding of how allocation algorithms affect quality of service. This requires developing a novel methodology for stochastic networks and their scaling properties. (3) The project aims to study a class of algorithms for sampling from high-dimensional sets, where the specific focus lies on algorithms that exploit boundaries.

If successful, the results of this research will lead to effective algorithms for large-scale random systems, along with accompanying qualitative insights and mathematical performance analysis. The results will for instance help in computing probabilities of rare but significant events. They will also help in understanding and managing large-scale service systems. Furthermore, they will aid in improving internal efficiencies in large-scale computer systems, which becomes ever more important in the face of rising energy costs and associated environmental impact.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On the research side, this project has led to a broad spectrum of tools for simulation and sampling algorithms for large-scale random systems. A particular focal point has been the development of simulation algorithms in the context of rare events. The PI developed a suite of algorithms that allow for simulating certain random processes for which no “exact” simulation tools were available prior to this project. The project supported the development of both the first exact algorithm in this space and the fastest known algorithm at the time of writing. Each algorithm was supported by mathematical theory establishing that the algorithms work correctly, as well as computer experiments confirming their use in practice. This project has also improved our understanding of how shared resources can be used and their capacity can be set. Specifically, it has produced several approximation results for algorithms, which provide insights into the trade-offs between information consumption, the resulting system performance, and required computational effort.

On the teaching side, this project has supported two PhD students during their studies. It has also led to the development of a PhD level course on Sampling Algorithms, which was both taught at the PI’s previous institution Georgia Tech and his current institution Columbia University. The PI has also developed a website where key concepts of probability can be learned and appreciated with 3D glasses, and he has introduced underrepresented high school students to the world of probability and industrial engineering through a computer game. The project has also supported the development of a tutorial at the INFORMS annual meeting about resource allocation problems.
